page.paragraph: CALL me Ishmael. Some tears ago⎯nevermind how longprecisely⎯have little or no money in my purse, and nothingparticular to interest me on shore, I thought I would sail abouta little and see the watery part of the world. It is a way I haveof driving off the spleen, and regulating the circulation. When-ever I find myself groving grim abouth the mouth; whenever itis a damp, drizzly November in my soul; whenever I find myselfinvoluntarily pausing before coffin warehouse, and bringing upthe rear of every funeral I meet; and especially whenever myhypos get such an upper hand of me, that is requires a strongmoral principel to prevent me from deliberately stepping intothe street and metodically knocking peoples hats off⎯then, Iaccount it high time to get to sea as soon as I can. This is mysubstitute for pistol and ball. With a philosophical flourish Cato throws himself upon his sword; I quietly take to theship. Rhere is nothing surprizing in this. If they but knew it,almost all men in their degree, some time or other, cherish verynrealy the same feelings toward the ocean with me.

There now is your insulan city of the Manhattoes, beltedround by wharves as Indian isles by coral reefs⎯commeres sur-rounds it with her surf. Right and left, the streets take youwaterward. Its extreme down-town is the battery, where thatnoble mole is washed by waves, and cooled by breezes, whicha few hours previous were out of sight of land. Look at thecrowds of water-gazers there.
